abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory outcomes,
            likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. Lessons learned emphasize the clarity
            of, and realistic operational, and institutional project
            objectives, as the main reasons for the overall project
            success, which helped the proactive participation, and
            commercial success of the Container Corporation of India
            (CONCOR), and allowed as well for the timely availability of
            counterpart funding. However, managing procurement issues
            revealed several weaknesses, i.e., qualifying criteria were
            not stringent enough to exclude financially, weak bidders;
            the pre-qualification criteria could have been strengthened
            by including stricter financial parameters for large
            contracts; and, there was no real devolution of procurement
            powers to the implementing agency. Instead, by excluding
            likely insolvent suppliers, procurement delays would have
            been minimized; indeed, lessons for the future point to the
            need of effective early preparation. As for the partial
            privatization of CONCOR, regardless of its initial
            commercial mindset, its full commercialization cannot be
            completed without a decrease in the Government of
            India's shareholding to less than fifty percent
            (private sector ownership is only thirty seven percent). It
            is important to note that recognizing the Bank's
            contribution in facilitating the introduction, and adoption
            of modern technology (container flatcar technology) proved
            successful, resulting in operational changes in respect to
            train operating speed, transit time, and service reliability.
